content.definition: Second most common visceral aneurysm (after splenic). More common in men, often multiple. Higher rupture risk than splenic (~20% present with rupture). Location within/outside liver parenchyma affects treatment approach and consequences of rupture.

clinical_features.epidemiology: 20% of visceral aneurysms, increasing incidence with more imaging

location.extrahepatic: Common hepatic, proper hepatic, gastroduodenal origin
location.intrahepatic: Right or left hepatic artery branches

presentation: Quincke triad: RUQ pain, hemobilia, jaundice (rupture into biliary tree)
treatment_thresholds: Smaller if mycotic, pregnant, or liver transplant
treatment_options: Surgical ligation with or without reconstruction

clinical_pearls: Quincke triad = classic but uncommon presentation of HAA rupture
Endovascular treatment preferred - hepatic artery can often be sacrificed due to dual supply
Intrahepatic HAA may need hepatic resection
Post-liver transplant patients at increased risk for mycotic HAA
GDA aneurysms included in hepatic artery category by some authors
